18:53 ü•Äü•Äü•Äü•Ä
There was a famous bridge collapse in the early 40s, the Tacoma narrows bridge, that was a suspension bridge nicknamed 'galloping gert' for the way it moved in the wind over the waterway it was on. A gale hit, the bridge went into harmonic oscillation and fell.   The engineer was a respected bridge engineer and the panel that investigated basically said that he didn't do anything wrong.  There was a trend at the time to make suspension bridges that were aesthetically pleasing to the eye. To do this they basically made the stiffe ning trusses very very light ( in comparison, look at a picture of the Brooklyn bridge , that had incredibly stiff trusses in the original design but then even more so when the bridge company wanted conventional trains to go on it). The trusses were too light for the kind of winds you get there, and it this oscillated in the wind and fell in a gale.   The chief of the panel was OH Ahman, who designed many of the bridges around NYC including the George Washington bridge..almost every member of the panel had designed bridges in that mode . Moses for example went back to Robert Moses , head of the TBTA, and they spent 10s of millions upgrading the Whitestone bridge with stiffening trusses bc it was over the entrance to long island sound that gets high winds and was designed the same way.   This is what happens with engineering. Either for aesthetic or monetary reasons they come up with a new design paradigm that others follow until something happens. One of the problems with the wind load issue was bridge designers were not well trained in aerodynamics. They didn't consult with experts in the field, like Von Karman of Caltech ( who was on the review panel and was critical of civil engineers understanding of wind load...plus I seem to recall the bridge deck had lift being generated as well.   I give the engineer credit that he listened to a question and actually investigated, as opposed to let's say the Titanic where the design, though it met existing British standards, was way too light, it had severe flex issues that likely contributed to its sinking ( in the 1990s they found the hidden report of the review board that came to that conclusion. The sister ships were beefed up after). There were people who questioned the design, especially after an earlier sister ship showed problems ).

Erol Beker (1918-1994) Beker came to the United States from Istanbul in 1950. He earned a master's degree in economics from the New School for Social Research and became founder and chairman of Beker Industries based in Greenwich, CT. He died at his home in Cannes, France, in 1994 and is inured in the Chapel.
Although it doesn't belong here, but üôÇ  Gravity I suppose that GRAVITY is caused by increasing permittivity and permeability (gradient) towards a material object (metals ‚Äì infinite permittivity, high permeability). Permittivity is inverse to stiffness, i.e., the speed of waves slows down towards a material object (curvature of light), but material objects accelerate towards a larger object because the gradient offers them less and less resistance to movement.  The explanation and conclusion below.  Relationship between refractive index, permittivity, and permeability:  The refractive index n is directly determined by the electric permittivity epsilon and the magnetic permeability mu. The relationship is: ‚ÄúThe refractive index n equals the square root of the product of the relative permittivity epsilon and the relative permeability mu.‚Äù  Most ordinary optical materials (like glass, water, plastics) have a relative permeability mu that is very close to one, so the relation simplifies to: ‚ÄúThe refractive index is approximately equal to the square root of the relative permittivity.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThe speed of light in a material equals the speed of light in vacuum divided by the refractive index, which is equivalent to one divided by the square root of the product of permittivity and permeability.‚Äù   This means the refractive index directly determines how much electromagnetic waves slow down inside medium.  For any wave in a medium (acoustic, elastic, or electromagnetic), the wave speed is controlled by two competing properties:  ‚Äúinertia‚Äù term - how hard it is to move or displace the medium - mass density œÅ - permeability Œº  ‚Äúrestoring‚Äù term - how strongly the medium pushes back -stiffness (bulk modulus) K - permittivity Œµ   So: permeability Œº plays the role of inertia (like mass density), and permittivity Œµ plays the role of stiffness (like a spring constant or bulk modulus).   Why Œµ behaves like stiffness  In electromagnetism, permittivity plays the role of compliance (inverse stiffness), not stiffness itself ‚Äî which is why the formula for EM wave speed has permittivity in the denominator, not in the numerator. Permeability then plays the role of inertial mass density. Permittivity means the medium polarizes easily, which means - it yields to the field (soft / compliant), it stores energy in polarization, the wave gets slowed down. This is the opposite of mechanical stiffness. Textbooks often say ‚ÄúŒµ is stiffness‚Äù only because high Œµ ‚Üí stronger material response, but from the wave-speed viewpoint it behaves like softness, not stiffness.   A high permittivity means - the medium polarizes strongly, the electric field ‚Äústores‚Äù a lot of potential energy in polarization ‚Üí its atoms/molecules are "easily deflected" and form dipoles ‚Üí the electric field is significantly "slowed down" inside the material. Material with low permittivity ‚Üí dipoles are hardly deflected ‚Üí the field penetrates almost without resistance (as in a vacuum or air).  Why Œº behaves like inertia  A high permeability means - the medium magnetizes strongly, i.e., it ‚Äúresponds‚Äù slowly/with lag to changes in magnetic induction just like mass density resists acceleration, permeability resists changes in magnetic field configuration   So in field-theory language: Œµ = how hard you push back when you are displaced, Œº = how heavy the field is to move Wave speed analogy  Mechanical wave for a sound wave in a material: ‚Äúwave speed equals the square root of stiffness divided by density.‚Äù Electromagnetic wave for light: ‚Äúwave speed equals one divided by the square root of permittivity times permeability.‚Äù Thus the structure is the same: acoustic ‚Äúspeed equals the square root of stiffness divided by density‚Äù stiff and light ‚Üí fast wave electromagnetic ‚Äúspeed equals one divided by the square root of permittivity times permeability‚Äù low inertia and low compliance ‚Üí fast wave   When all previous notes are put together, the following conclusion can be drawn:  I suppose that GRAVITY is caused by increasing permittivity and permeability (gradient) towards a material object (metals ‚Äì infinite permittivity, high permeability). The presence of a medium (aether - whatever we call it today, e.g. relic neutrinos - Bob Greenyer and others) is important for this assumption. Permittivity is inverse to stiffness, i.e., the speed of waves slows down towards a material object (curvature of light), but material objects accelerate towards a larger object because the gradient offers them less and less resistance to movement. High permittivity - low stiffness, low "resistance" for material objects - higher speed. Low permittivity of vacuum - high stiffness - high wave speed, but high "resistance" for a moving material object. Paradoxically, flying a spaceship in a vacuum is worse, less efficient, and slower than moving toward a place with higher permittivity and lower permeability from a place with higher  permeability and lower permittivity. And therein lies a clue as to how to build a propulsion system that would change the environment electromagnetically (especially the permittivity) AROUND a spaceship.  All this leads, for example, to the fractal toroidal moment (ball lightning, plasmoids, static electricity, ...) of Bob Greenyer, EVO - Ken Shoulders, Takaaki Matsumoto, Dubovik, John Archibald Wheeler, Nikola Tesla, Guy Obolensky (Mach disc, The mechanics of time revisited, The force is faster than its radiation, The magnetic force is faster than light), and many many others.   The most common elements in the composition of the Earth‚Äôs crust (by mass): Oxygen (O) ~46% the most paramagnetic natural gas Silicon (Si) ~28% high permitivity Aluminum (Al) ~8% paramagnetic Iron (Fe) ~5% ferromagnetic  The whole Earth (core + mantle + crust) Iron (Fe) ~32% Oxygen (O) ~30% Silicon (Si) ~15% Magnesium (Mg) ~14%   The permittivity of a perfect metal is considered infinite because it completely blocks internal electric fields (this is precisely one of the properties of Greenyer's fractal toroidal moment - THE NON-RADIATING BOUNDARY). However, in real-world applications, especially at high frequencies, metals exhibit a complex-valued relative permittivity that is frequency-dependent and can be approximated with a complex refractive index. This leads to the use of frequency-dependent models like the Drude model to describe their behavior, where the permittivity is not truly infinite.  Metals contain a large number of free electrons that move freely and shield any applied electric field, effectively canceling it out inside the conductor. This makes the dielectric constant (relative permittivity) infinite, as it is directly proportional to the material's permittivity, and the metal completely resists the formation of an electric field within it.

Engineers must ALWAYS be HIGHLY SKEPTICAL of Contractors proposing changes.  I work for a manufacturer of engineered rotating machinery.  At the start of the submittal phase of a recent project, we put in RFIs and explained to the engineer how part of their piping system HAD to be slightly re-designed to work with the type of equipment specified.  Once the senior engineering staff understood the underlying principles, they agreed.  The change was only about $100K.  But during Construction, the Contractor comes up with this idea to save the Owner $50K (and put the other $50K in their pocket), BY REVERSING THE CHANGE MADE 18 MONTHS BEFORE.  And here is where it all goes wrong.  The senior engineers are no longer involved on a daily basis.  All the submittals are approved, and there are lots of inspectors, but the level of engineering expertise is not the same.  So the change gets approved by a junior Engineer.  Once our startup engineer gets out in the field to commission the equipment, he points out that it WILL NOT WORK with the changes they made.  So it all has to be changed back.

Deciding not to tell the affected public or those working in the building that they had discovered it could potentially collapse at the first sign of some heavy winds strikes me as extraordinarily problematic, both legally and ethically. Worst case scenario if telling - people make an informed decision about whether to move to a different area while the building is remedied (hardly ‚Äúmass panic‚Äù). Worst case scenario if not telling - the avoidable deaths of potentially tens of thousands of people who you deliberately kept ignorant of the risks facing them. Remember  this wasn‚Äôt scientists or government working out how much information to provide the public about constant, natural, unavoidable risks that have a perhaps low probability of materialising but catastrophic consequences if they do (like the risks of asteroids hitting earth). This was private actors who collectively and carelessly made catastrophic errors in the construction of a major, publicly feted building; it was their collective error that was putting the public at active risk; the risks were now all known to them, they were very high, the consequences would be catastrophic; and the consequences would be entirely avoidable if only they bothered informing the affected public of their error and the resulting risks. Not acceptable.

Writing as a physicist, it strikes me that quartering winds were originally not taken into consideration and not required to be taken into consideration by the regulations. The assumption that the worst case is a wind that directly hits one of the faces is natural, but taking into account that combining two such loads to form a quartering wind is, in a first approximation, a relatively simple calculation, one would assume that you just do it. After all, this is a multi-multi-million operation.

It‚Äôs crazy how little engineers are taught welding and what it implies, welded joints are meant to bend and twist and contract, and if weld joints are done properly up to code, they should be stronger than the material itself. Even bad welds should be at minimum the same load capacity as long as they pass. Same with another guy I know designing tanks, who didn‚Äôt know what stainless filler rod should be used for tig welding stainless to carbon.  Had the beams been properly welded from the beginning there would‚Äôve been absolutely no issue holding the weight, but whenever you put bolts into the equation the stress isn‚Äôt transferred evenly as it is with a welded joint. There‚Äôs a lot of science behind it, but if you‚Äôre ever building something that needs to be strong, weld it. It‚Äôll hold 100% better 100% of the time. "During its construction in the 1970s, the John Hancock Tower experienced a critical design flaw where 500-pound glass panels detached and fell to the ground, leading to streets being closed and the building being boarded with plywood.   The problem was diagnosed as a brittle window design and was resolved by replacing all 10,334 panes with tempered glass. The building also required internal reinforcing to prevent dangerous swaying from high winds, but it has since been strengthened and remains a stable landmark."

these become laborius...here is the AI answer...A student named Diane Hartley saved the Citicorp Center (now 601 Lexington Avenue) in NYC by questioning the building's structural integrity regarding the forces of diagonal winds. Her questions, part of a senior thesis project, led her to contact the engineering firm, revealing that a flaw in the design, combined with a change from welded to bolted joints for wind bracing, left the building vulnerable to collapse. This prompted the engineering firm to undertake a covert, overnight repair operation to weld the connections, preventing disaster.

The chain of custody issue. Architect designs a building. States specs and requirements. Related services down to the GC begin to produce or delegate production of BOM's to buy materials.  Then in the trenches a smart GC engineer or designer says "WOW we can save the client XXX if we bolt other than weld". However a bolted structure is never a rigid unitized structure. How were the skyscrapers of renown built during the 30 's and 40's hot weld rivets . Heated red hot, pounded in place by Popeye types with muscles like a cantaloupe using huge sledge hammers. Result better than bolts cheaper than massive weld set ups and durable 80+ years later  The thing the video missed, and I would argue with the original designer is he was a structure guy. Not a fastener guy. Bolts stretch, bolts wear at the collar, and around the circumference when torqued to spec if the structure moves the wear is amplified.   It's simple welding done PROPERLY makes 2 pieces of metal ONE. Bolting makes 2 pieces of metal bolted together and never really one.  This is really a matter of the original design being circumvented as the saying was years ago stepping over a dollar to save a dime.  Clearly the head architect/designer had no personal knowledge someone way down the food  chain had a eureka moment and yelled bolt it don't weld it.  When the head guy who designed the building heard of the change he was non nonchalant about the change which I think was a mistake in the beginning. Like a say a structure guy not a fastener guy  However some lowerling it appears in his own organization approved the substitute in a Oh Well it's cheaper moment  This just shouts welding is better because if done well it is permanent as compered to bolting as 2 pieces joined with a fastener under the conditions will wear out or at best require re torque or replace every few years.  Well back to the drawing board the original design with welds was better, expensive as a retro fit but better.  Moral always involve people with metal fitment specific knowledge this designer was clearly a structural genius but was not equipped to deal with fasteners or weld technology on a building that danced on the foundation during wind.
Typical human behaviour. Men mastered building very high structures so let's build something harder.

If you are certain of the outcome, regardless of what would really happen, and you live by a moral and ethical code, and you move to prevent the outcome as dictated by those codes then you have committed a neutral act. It is only if inaction is considered a neutral act that action should be considered virtuous. I love how the solution to the building in the first place, the TMD, is like a modern reversed version of the way the Japanese made tall Pagodas to survive hurricanes/typhoons, tsunamis, and earthquakes.  In Pagodas, they use lots of triangular shapes on a square building and the center has a huuuge wooden pillar in it as a structural support, with the interlocking levels of the tower designed to sway freely around it. The TMD reverses this, with the building remaining still and the center stabilizing weight doing the swaying.  It's always fun to see a building idea pop up in multiple places across the world independently of eachother. <3

The greatest thing about structural engineering is that I can choose not to do it.
But you didn‚Äôt really explain in detail why exactly it was the 30th floor
And before even knowing how many floors the Citicorp building had I immediately knew the reason the 30th floor was the most at risk because I knew that however much floors the building had the 30 had to be more than half the total number of floors. Reason: at a lesser amount (counting from top to bottom) the forces and dynamics would be so little it could be counted as static but as it gets closer to the half way mark it would be noticeable but not dangerous because it would be negated by the upward opposite force of the rest of the building. But then as all those little movements and tensions increase along with the weight of the Newtons above(imagine being 100,000 fathoms under water you'd be crushed to death) and the floors above become greater in number than the floors below which are supporting the N above, even the slightest movements of the above floors would strain the lesser amount of floors below. Now factoring wind which increases all that force or N and this becomes a catastrophic problem. Lets say the lower part of the building's ability at anytime to bear load is 100N but the force being exerted upon it from above and around is 100Nx10000000. It's common sense. Force in this case doesn't increase by N+N but rather by NXN so by the time it got to more than half aka the 30th floor the building was in jeopardy and revealed this madman's stupidity.   How was this guy so stupid and careless! This is literally malpractice no different than a doctor using temporary sutures on an arteries and then giving the patient adrenaline.

If the error falls inside standard practices, then steps will be taken for neglagence, and the punishment is administered accordingly, but reduced due to moral honesty. In both Canada (where this originated) and the US, there is a custom (not any kind of requirement, just a custom) of a newly licensed engineer receiving a small piece of jewelry called an Iron Ring.  This ring is work on the pinkie of the dominant hand, and serves as a constant reminder that when engineers make mistakes, people die. The rings are not made of historical metal (there is a false legend that they are made of metal salvaged from the Quebec Bridge disasters, but that type of steel is not suitable for jewelry) but the Canadian practice was directly inspired by the Quebec Bridge disasters.  The Quebec Bridge, a rail bridge at Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, collapsed during construction, TWICE, because of engineering errors, both times with heavy loss of life.  Rudyard Kipling was asked to write a ceremony, known as The Calling of an Engineer (the details of most of the ceremony are kept private, although the promise, not an oath but a promise, the Engineer being Called makes is known, and it essentially is a promise to own up to mistakes, accept criticism and correction, and ask for help as needed).  I also ran across a story about one engineering professor's introductory lecture in a first-year engineering course.  He told the students something along the lines of, "If you are right in this course 90% of the time, you will earn an A+.  If you are right 90% of the time in your professional work, you will spend the rest of your life in prison for gross negligence."  Reality is extremely unforgiving of engineering errors.

I understand that cutting costs where possible is part of the process of construction, and that the vast majority of the time there are lots of substitutions that can be made without sacrificing safety at all.   However, I do think that if you are a corporation paying for a new building, you have to decide - do you want a one-of-a-kind building that uses extremely uncommon or even never-done-before techniques in order to meet the extremely specific constraints you have in an aesthetically pleasing way? Or do you want to save money?  Most of the time, those substitutions that can be easily made are ones where the people involved are extremely familiar with the materials and techniques and have years of experience thinking about how they all work together. They‚Äôre not going to have that the first time they work on a brand new concept that defies convention in multiple different ways. Make the substitutions once everyone involved has built or at least studied 10 buildings like this. Or even 1. Not on the first one to exist.   If you want to innovate with things where people‚Äôs lives are at stake - the first one is gonna be expensive. That‚Äôs the inherent tradeoff of innovation with stuff like this. When lives are at stake, you start by doing it right, not by doing it cheap. The more people whose lives will depend on it, the more you have to overestimate risks and overdo the safety measures the first time around. The time for figuring out how to cut costs is later - once you‚Äôve had a chance to make that first prototype a reality and study it thoroughly. At this point in human existence we should be well aware that we always will find things we failed to consider when something moves from theory to reality. Why would you add more potential points of failure? Innovation costs. Either pay up and deal with it, or put the supports in the corners and save money. Attempting to do both should not have been on the table.

A historical example of the consequences of NOT acting when you recognize an engineering flaw would be the loss of the USS Macon. Dr Karl Arnstein (probably the one of the first actual stress analysts ever) saw that adaptations done to his airship design, specifically the altering of its tailfin dimensions, would reduce its main anchor points from three to two and cause the leading edge to basically "float" without sufficient support. Unlike Luftschiffbau Zeppelin where they both own and operate their airships, Arnstein and Goodyear could only plead with the Navy to allow the structural repairs to occur, and only based on the Navy's own timeline priorities. Fleet maneuvers ensued, damage to the fin root progressed as predicted (in full view for everybody involved) and when the Macon was on its way back to base its fin tore off and was lost into the ocean.
If only politicians and people in power would learn this novel concept of "admitting to mistakes." üôÑ

It is not without reason that any square-shaped building that stands on four pillars has those situated AT THE CORNERS instead of in-between. Not only enlarges that the distance in-between those pillars to the maximum that is possible giving the building a wider base of support, also there's no weight 'sticking out' passed every pillar in the smaller-based configuration as the setup we see here has that acts as undesirable counter-weight, further reducing stability.

Great video but as a physics type channel can you please get pronunciation of kilometre correct.  The word kilometre should be pronounced kilo-metre, not kilom-metre, because it follows the same metric naming convention as all other SI units. We say kilogram (kilo + gram), kilojoule (kilo + joule), and kilolitre (kilo + litre). The prefix ‚Äúkilo-‚Äù always stands on its own to mean 1,000, and there‚Äôs no reason kilometre should be the only exception. Consistency in pronunciation reflects consistency in the metric system itself.

Correction....The flaw in the Citicorp Center's design was discovered by Diane Hartley, a Princeton University undergraduate student, who identified a critical vulnerability related to "quartering winds" that could have led to the building's collapse.  Her findings were brought to the attention of William LeMessurier, the building's chief structural engineer, although initially, he dismissed her concerns.  Subsequent investigations confirmed the danger, leading to a secret and urgent repair effort to reinforce the building's structure.

Holy ish! This story is crazy because in February of 78, I chose the CITICORP building as my project for my structural project assignment. It was my 2ns semester. I went to the building in March of 78 to do a walk through, do some sketches, and take notes. The first ing I remember was how much the building swayed. I mentioned it to my one of my professors, Bill Berenman he's German. My other professor, I don't remember his name, but his firm designed the Central Commercail High School located at 34th and Park Ave.  I wish I still had my notes on that project. I'd like to see what my grade was, but that was 45 years ago.  Another very noticeable issue was the finishing touches grouting in the corners. It was horrible for such a major project. Back then, there were no cell phones, so I had to sketch everything for my notes.   Another class project I had was the 42nd St bus terminal. My university was right around the corner. I had many notes, and sketches from close observations of that project as well.   My college years back, then we're filled with so many major landmark construction. I'm not an engineer  but I have been in construction all my life and even I can tell you how unstable that building looks.
I worked in that building for 6 years on the 38th floor. My office had windows on two sides and massive diagonal braces that blocked the windows by 10 feet of the corner. Even in 2009 the building swayed like a sailboat in moderate winds. What they don‚Äôt talk about is two important factors: 1) The building is the tallest building on the east side with only the Bloomberg building on 59st as a comparably sized building meaning that there are no other buildings to act as windbreaks to break up the wind before it hits. 2) The building is on 53 and Lex 4 blocks from the East River. The wind from both the East and the River and The Hudson River, are known for their ferocity. The East River Eagle comes straight from Long Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean and has miles of flat open land to pickup speed. Anything above the 20th floor gets hit by the nearly full brunt of the wind. I remember having huge items slam into my wind, full size umbrellas hitting the 37 floor. Not to mention the birds caught by the wind and slammed against the windows upside down with their wings tucked in. And people sensitive to the sway became nauseous on a regular basis. It‚Äôs a weird building all in all

When she realised that, according to her calculations, the building could collapse at any moment, she wrote a letter to William LeMessurier, raising concern. I have read a couple comments on here regarding who to blame for this incident, we all know its mainly the architect but there are many issues here regarding the whole process of this building construction.   The Architect's firm: I understand firms typically employ multiple architects for various projects. However, not communicating with the architect regarding this huge structural design change, and approving it on his behalf is absurd.   He would have done new calculations and maybe requested more bolts in the moment. He's an active thinker; came up with a revolutionary engineering method (Tuned Mass Damper) while designing that building, why wouldn't you contact him?   I'm sure this wouldn't have changed the discoveries later on, like the quarterly wind discovery a few months after construction, but I am certain he would have thought of either a different cost-saving method, denied the switch, or requested more bolts on that building.  The firm should have at least asked for his opinion before approval, his view of the building is unique, it's his design after all.

Winds a ‚Äú110 km/hr‚Äù (68-mph)‚Ä¶.leaves out a very important detail.  During the design, wind codes were evaluated in both orthogonal directions as per code.   However, after construction, it was an engineering student doing their study that discovered if the wind speed was not orthogonal, or diagonal, the building could fall.  The fix was to transfer the lateral loads back to the center of the building. This is not typical design.  Both the discovery and solution were ahead of their time.

There's an interesting aspect on the issue that is: Why do the contractors propose the alternative? In construction contracts contractors aren't automatically entitled to saved cost, so the client could really just tell the contractor to fxxk off and pocket the money saved. So either the contract encourages cost saving or they have made an agreement to share the savings, but that also brings out the problem where contractors could in theory propose unbiuldable methods to cheat the system, so contracts usually forbiddens any deviations from design, and the client must first agree on the proposal to make it legal, so then the problem becomes if the client knows about the proposal, and whether they know the implications of it, though in either case the contractor and consultants are expected to know what they are doing, it's just the severity of the situation could vary depending on the contract.

20:20 - its not a 1/16 chance... its a 1/16 chance WITH a power outage (assuming that wasn't part of the 1/16 calc). the compounding chance likely puts it back near the 1/110year range.... relatively small error ;) but still.   I for one am surprised the 1/4 case wasn't looked at sooner. Im not a structural eng (electrical instead)... but even so the idea that you can knock the legs form the corner of a cube into the centre, and then not consider the fact diagonal loads ultimately need to be transferred to the corners of that smaller square 'diagonally inside' the bigger square, with a resultant 'leaver' advantage, seems a big miss. Harder to do without any modern computers, but still...  just looking at the ratio of side lengths of a 'square diagonally in a square' is ~7:10... ie 1.4, the same ratio of concern mentioned here. And all i did was measure a square in a square (or... calculate the adjacent length using the side of the building as the hypotenuse)... and that took less time than writing this comment... your just gonna have to believe me (or not... it is the internet) when I claim 1.4 was in my head before it was mentioned here too...  :/   A team not consulting the prior engineer(s) when making changes to a design, while not surprising, is equally silly. I use tuned mass dampers too- as wolf killers.  Stringed instruments sometimes resonate on a particular tone, say an Ab, much louder than other tones, a so-called "wolf tone".  There are various ways of trying to get around these wolves, but sometimes the only solution is a wolf killer.  This is a tuning fork, basically a mass on springs, tuned to the wolf tone, and damped, usually by being wrapped in rubber for friction.  They are installed by first sticking them temporarily on the outside of the belly, trying various locations to get the best damping.  Because no one likes the way they look, they are usually then glued permanently to the inside on the sweet spot, which is a ticklish operation.  A fascinating story of architecture and human drama.  Tnanks.  cheers from an instrument maker in sunny Vienna, Scott

In 1978, a significant structural flaw was discovered in the Citicorp Center (now Citigroup Center) in New York City, leading to secret emergency repairs that potentially averted disaster. This discovery involved two students who played important roles in identifying the issue. Princeton University engineering student Diane Hartley was writing her senior thesis about the Citicorp Center's design in June 1978. During her analysis, she calculated stresses from quartering winds (winds hitting the building diagonally) and found them higher than the maximum expected stress values provided by the building's design firm. When she raised concerns with a junior staff member at the firm, she was assured the building could handle the necessary forces, though she documented her concerns in her thesis. Around the same time, Lee DeCarolis, an architecture student at New Jersey Institute of Technology, was working on a report about the building. His professor expressed reservations about the structure, which DeCarolis relayed to William LeMessurier, the chief structural engineer. These student inquiries, along with LeMessurier's discovery that bolts had been substituted for the welded joints he had specified in the design, prompted him to recalculate the wind loads on the building. He found that the combination of quartering winds and bolted joints made the building vulnerable to collapse in high winds

I'm surprised that this was the first use of a tuned-mass damper in a skyscraper. The concept was not new. The 1967 Chevrolet Camaro convertible had tuned mass dampers on the front corners to minimize body shake and the Garrard record changer I bought in 1974 had what was effectively a tuned mass damper in the form of a rubber mounted counterweight. It seems that thought of putting something like that 1,000 feet in the air just hadn't occurred to anyone yet, although I should add that the examples I mentioned were passive dampers and the one in the Citicorp tower, with the story mentioning backup generators,  seems to have been an active one.
On January 18, 1978, just 3 months before this flaw started to get attention, the Hartford Civic Center collapsed in the original "Blizzard of '78", which gave up that title to an even bigger storm in February. In that collapse, a space-frame roof had been designed with software that was coded on the assumption that all the diagonal members of the structure would always be in tension, as they would be with an evenly spread snow load. But the 1978 storm had winds that redistributed the snow and rendered that assumption invalid, allowing the roof to collapse. Fortuitously, the city was shut down that night and the building was empty. The software was re-written and subsequent buildings, including the Gerald R. Ford Library, have been built safely. But, assumptions about tension VS. compression must have been on a lot of minds that year.

15:24 I dont get that, because it was the first thing I thought about. Not for the reasons that mattered but just because its where the supports were not so seemed like the most important thing to consider.
I showed my Dad, who is a retired structural project engineer who worked for the largest engineering firm back in the day, he specialized in industrial engineering because in his words, "it wasnt as bare bones for profit, we got to design things properly" as commercial engineering like highrises where saving money is the name of the game so to say. I am a formwork carpenter who has worked on many high rises through the years, now im a safety officer. My Dad has built sawmills, pulp and paper plants, oil field plants, US submarine base, American Iraq bases, melting nuclear waste into glass and storing it under ground which didnt go anywhere. LNG, etc  I showed him this video and he really liked it. He said it might be too technical for the average person and I lol'd because you did a good job explaining things and I think this video is easy to follow. He said it's now code to do a wind tunnel test for every high rise build, i'm not sure when that became code though, he didnt say.   He said the bolts they must have ordered to spec would be pretty dang big if there were only to be four of them. I forget what he said, but an inch and a half or something, I forget. He also said it's also mandatory to do the quarter wind calculation thing, which he couldnt come up with the word, I had to fill in when he was searching for the word, I am worried about dementia, for my grandfather had it. He's almost 80. He was in charge of a saw mill that Japan paid for in Fiji as reparations for what they did to them in WW2,  as an apology. We lived there when I was young. The Fijian workers lived on site. They jackhammered concrete with elastic slingshots with hardened metal chisel, just wild eh.   My Dad said the Chevron beams are very good and still used all the time, but the beams use friction bolts and not bearing bolts. Bearing bolts, picture a bolt in a hole, with a gap around the bolt connecting two girders. There would be clamping force mating the beams, but there is a gap around the bolts, call it 1/16th of an inch total. He said the holes in the 1970s would not be equidistant perfectly matched from hole to hole to slide a whole 1/16th but the mating surface, although torqued down together, would still slide past each other, compression and tension. When there are SO MANY bolted girder beams making up the whole building, that's A LOT of shifting, and the video did not touch on this. A modern building would use friction bolts which are tight in the hole in the mating surfaces, and cant allow slippage of the mating surfaces. I think that's what my Dad said, it was happy hour night and we were tipsy, my bad.   hmmm, what else did he say. He sarcastically said, tuned mass dampeners are great, "when they work." duno what that was supposed to mean. He did say in the 60s and 70s engineers were trying a lot of new things without fully knowing all the variables, and said when computers became more common in the 80s, they learned a whole lot about the things they were doing wrong. I found that kind of disconcerting but interesting.   He also said "fill in welding" still isnt the end all and be all.   He said none of the buildings in New York have been built with seismic consideration. He said chevron bracing is great but it also bears load all the time, and shear braces should typically not bear a load, if you can help it. How would you build a skyscraper with no structure at the edges and assume diagonal winds would have no effect?!?!
In 1981, a 23 story building was opened in Hartford, Ct. It had a few floors on the ground and then an opened space. Supports came from the center and went out at a diagonal to the edges of the building, like the "chevrons" here. You can look through the supports and right through the middle of the building. Right before they opened they thought "is this safe?" So they put pallets of weights in different positions in the building and took readings. They deemed it safe and opened. It's 40 years later and it's still there.

Had it occurred fifty miles away, buildings here would have collapsed, and so many would have died. This city is built on soft soil, so the movement is magnified.  It's just a matter of time before a quake, stronger than the designers of these buildings calculated for, hits a big city, and a massive destruction occurs.
The first person to warn about the structural problem of the Citicorp Center in Manhattan was Diane Hartley, an undergraduate architecture student at Princeton. In 1978, while working on her thesis, Hartley noticed a potential vulnerability in the building‚Äôs design related to how it would withstand quartering winds (winds hitting the building at its corners). She called the building‚Äôs chief structural engineer, William LeMessurier, to ask how the structure handled these wind loads. This inquiry prompted LeMessurier to re-examine his calculations, which ultimately led to the discovery of a serious structural deficiency that required urgent repairs

Tuned Mass Dampers are passive devices that do not require power so there would be no need for emergency generators. If emergency generators are required then the system must be an Active Mass Damper which uses sensors, controllers and actuators to move the mass - requiring electrical power for the hydraulic pumps and controllers.

The ethical dimension here is not the church. No, really, safety coefficients decide durability, first of all. On any civilian building, the safety coefficients are 2.0. If lives depend directly on the structural integrity, like in a roll-a-coaster or a plane, then they are doubled again, the coefficients being 4.0. So every element of the structure must resist to 4 times the calculated load. But yeah, even one of the richest places on Earth has its dark corners, and some buildings carry a reputation that goes beyond just old bricks and bad plumbing.  When you talk about the ‚Äúmost dangerous building‚Äù in Manhattan, it‚Äôs not just about physical danger like structural issues ‚Äî it can also mean a building‚Äôs history, crime rates, mysterious past, or even health hazards. Some buildings are literally ticking time bombs due to what they‚Äôre made of (like asbestos), while others are wrapped in stories of crime, corruption, or tragedy.  A few places come to mind depending on what angle you're looking at:  NYCHA buildings (public housing projects) in neighborhoods like East Harlem or the Lower East Side have long struggled with poor maintenance, outdated safety standards, and higher crime. It‚Äôs not fair to blame the residents ‚Äî it‚Äôs more about the system failing them.  Then there‚Äôs One57, the supertall luxury skyscraper nicknamed the ‚ÄúBillionaire Building.‚Äù It‚Äôs not dangerous in the usual sense, but it's symbolic of Manhattan‚Äôs real estate bubble, where billionaires park money in apartments no one lives in, while homelessness grows. In a social sense, that‚Äôs dangerous.  Or consider abandoned or forgotten structures‚Äîsome pre-war buildings have had fires, collapsed stairwells, or even toxic mold and lead. There are places that look safe on the outside but are nightmares inside.  Some even say 432 Park Avenue, one of the tallest residential buildings in the world, is "dangerous" in a different way ‚Äî super rich owners have complained about engineering flaws, strange creaking sounds, and flooding from broken pipes. Imagine dropping millions on an apartment only to have your ceiling leak ‚Äî wild.  Let‚Äôs not forget the psychological angle either ‚Äî some buildings carry dark energy from tragedies, suicides, or crimes that happened there. A building can look sleek and shiny but still hold a haunted vibe that makes people uneasy.  So yeah, the most dangerous building in Manhattan might not be falling apart ‚Äî it might just be the one that‚Äôs hiding the most behind its walls.

The initial engineer didn‚Äôt find the flaw. Diane Hartley, an undergraduate engineering student at Princeton University (not a graduate student, as sometimes claimed). In 1978, while working on her senior thesis, Hartley analyzed the Citicorp Center‚Äôs structural design. She noticed that the building‚Äôs unique structure‚Äîelevated on stilts with a tuned mass damper to counteract swaying‚Äîmight be vulnerable to ‚Äúquartering winds. The engineers initially resisted the idea but later decided to check and SHE was right. Give that girl some credit.

Ouff. Mechanical engineer here. Bolts, welding ... That was not the real issue here (the original weldings perhaps would have been also faulty). The real issue is the fact, that they did completely wrong assumptions on a somehow progressive design. It is definitely not(!) counter-intuitive, that the major wind force happens diagonally. Wind force or air resistance is always calculated with the biggest surface the wind or air hits. And - surprise - the diagonal surface of a block is much bigger than the orthogonal surface. This is no rocket science and known for hundreds of years, I really can't believe, they missed that.

Just a minor Structural Engi correction. When calculating (even with Safety Factors), your numbers always round up, even if they're close to the other number. I. E. Number of bolts (calculated) = 3.05. Number of bolts (to be installed) = 4. We never round down.

Great video! Three strong book recommendations: Why Buildings Stand Up by Mario Salvadori, Why Buildings Fall Down, by Matthys Levy and Mario Salvadori, and To Engineer Is Human: The Role of Failure in Structural Design, by Henry Petroski. The last of these describes the Hyatt Regency walkway collapse in Kansas City in 1981. Here, too, there was an engineering change made to the original design which led to the ultimate failure. Though in the Hyatt case, the original design was extremely difficult, if not impossible to implement, because it required single rods to be suspended from the ceiling and threaded through holes in the supports of both an upper and a lower walkway. The actual implementation has one set of rods from the ceiling supporting the upper walkway and one set suspending the lower walkway from the upper walkway. Thus, the nuts and washers supporting the upper walkway endured the load of *both* walkways.

A New Theory of Space Expansion, Black Holes, and Gravitational Lensing  I propose a new understanding of the universe where black holes are not only consuming matter but also actively ejecting space itself. This fundamental process explains many major cosmic phenomena without the need for dark matter or dark energy.  1. Atoms and the Nature of Space:  Atoms are about ninety-nine percent empty space. If you compress an atom by pushing electrons toward the nucleus, the external space does not simply vanish ‚Äî the space remains. Similarly, when matter is compressed in black holes, the "freed" external space is ejected outward. This process continuously creates new space, explaining the expansion of the universe without requiring the galaxies to actually move apart.  2. Expansion of the Universe:  The ejection of space by black holes and other massive objects pushes galaxies apart, even if they are gravitationally moving toward each other. It is not galaxies flying away into empty space, but space itself growing between them, driven by countless black holes across the universe.  3. The Frozen Image at the Event Horizon:  The reason we observe objects "frozen" at a black hole‚Äôs event horizon is because, as space is ejected at near-light speed, it stretches and slows the light coming from infalling matter. To an outside observer, it looks as if the object is eternally stuck at the horizon, frozen in time.  4. Formation of Spiral Galaxies:  Because black holes eject space unevenly and with intense forces, they start to rotate. This rotation of the black hole causes the surrounding matter to form into a spiral structure, naturally explaining why so many galaxies have spiral shapes. The spiral shape is a direct consequence of the black hole spinning as it ejects enormous amounts of space.  5. Relativistic Jets and Hawking Radiation:  The relativistic jets emitted from black holes, as well as Hawking radiation, can be seen as side effects of this intense space ejection process. Some matter and energy are blasted out along the axis of rotation as part of the black hole‚Äôs mechanism to eject space, explaining why we see powerful jets emerging from galactic centers.  6. Gravitational Lensing ‚Äì A New Perspective:  When we observe gravitational lensing, we are seeing very old light from distant galaxies. The light shows the galaxy as it was billions of years ago and where it was billions of years ago when the light began its journey. If, during that time, the galaxy itself moved closer to us, it could now lie directly between its own ancient light paths and us, the observers. In that case, the galaxy itself would cause the gravitational lensing of its own ancient images. Thus, the gravitational lensing we observe could often be caused by the galaxy itself, not necessarily by some invisible dark matter halo. This also fits with the idea that galaxies are moving toward each other, but the continuous ejection of space between them makes it appear that the universe is expanding.  7. Gravitational Waves:  Gravitational waves can be understood as ripples created when the intense ejection of space is disturbed, for example, during black hole mergers. Instead of thinking of it only as a disturbance of spacetime, it is also a disturbance in the ongoing flow and ejection of space.  8. No Need for Dark Matter or Dark Energy:  This model naturally explains gravitational lensing, cosmic expansion, galaxy structure, gravitational waves, and Hawking radiation ‚Äî without invoking dark matter or dark energy. The ejection of space by black holes and other dense structures provides all the necessary effects.

The part that people don't seem to understand is that disasters are usually not one failure point, but various failure points that coincidentally align.   The first one here was: 1.  Engineering Design that did not account for wind from all sides.  These are factors that not everyone or engineer used to think about because it was not "common" and were freak accidents. Now, due to the nature of objects lasting 100 years+ we have to consider it.  2.  Post Engineering, Construction changes.   While he planned for the building to have things done a certain way, due to the physic laws.  Actuality was that they decided to cut corners, as all construction projects tend to try to do.  3. A potential failure in an area that we are not fully yet aware of.  4. The weather pattern that is the rare scenario to happen.   They had al the markings of a future Skybridge/Champlain accident.  Thankfully, the engineer realized after some calls that there was a reason people were trying to get the information.  And so he decided to reanalyze it to provide more accurate perspective with more knowledge (current assignment gave him more experience).   At that point, he did the right thing.  The important thing was in managing situation and quickly correcting it. So it doesn't become a string of errors that eventually leads to a calamity.   The right path was taken. A lot of people are wondering why the Citicorp Center wouldn‚Äôt have fallen straight down like the Twin Towers, so here‚Äôs a clear explanation:  The World Trade Center collapsed almost straight down because the damage was spread across the building very evenly. After the planes hit, the fires weakened the steel across several floors at the same time. When the structure finally gave out, everything above the impact zone dropped straight onto the floors below, and the force pushed downward, causing the towers to fall mostly into their own footprint.  The Citicorp Center was a completely different situation. It had a hidden flaw: they used bolts instead of welding the major braces inside the building. Those bolts weren‚Äôt strong enough to handle heavy wind from a diagonal angle (what‚Äôs called quartering winds). If the building had been hit by a strong enough storm from the wrong direction, the failure wouldn‚Äôt have been even ‚Äî it would have started on one side.  When that happens, a skyscraper doesn‚Äôt just collapse straight down. It starts to lean. Once a building that big starts leaning, it can‚Äôt stop ‚Äî gravity pulls it over fast. That‚Äôs why engineers were so scared. They were worried that Citicorp Center would fall sideways into nearby buildings and cause a chain reaction across several blocks. It wouldn‚Äôt have looked anything like the Twin Towers collapse ‚Äî it would have been way more chaotic.  So to sum it up:  Twin Towers collapsed mostly straight down because the structure weakened evenly. Citicorp Center would have fallen sideways because the failure would have been uneven and started at a weak point. Hope this helps clear it up!

The part at 3:00 should be a part of every presentation on solid mechanics (i.e., a core course in the mechanically oriented engineering programs).  The stilts being on the face centers, as opposed to the the corners, essentially reduces the moment-bending radius of gyration by the square root of 2 (and increasing the stress load by that same square root of 2).  Indeed, the importance of the radius of gyration is the reason why the I-beam is the preferred shape for a structural member, and why a hollow circular tube of a certain cross-sectional area is preferred to solid circle of the same area (i.e., with a smaller radius).

In the old days, engineers accepted material defects and human error and materials deteriorating with age in a simple process...We called it "the fudge factor" Here is how it works: Figure out what will work at a minimum..then double it...then add 50% more, just to be sure.  A good example of this was WW2 US submarines. Test depth was 350 ft, crush depth was estimated to be 500 ft. Several submarines are known to have survived 800+ft dives.

"Despite the risk, they decided not to tell the public, even the office workers in the building" - like, this is insane to me. How this video does it with such a cheery tone is beyond me. We're meant to laud this guy's ethics, and that telephone lines were created to spy on the building's instability?
This story seems to still be a mystery. An author of the NIST study claims "According to our calculations, if the building had been safely designed for head-on winds, then it would have been safe for quartering winds, regardless of the connection details, i.e., whether the multi-story diagonal braces were bolted or welded together, and the strengthening of the diagonal braces would have been unnecessary." He also wrote "Still, [the building's designers'] measurements of base moments in the 1970s wind tunnel tests should have led them to the same conclusion that corner winds do not govern the design, but face winds do, so the rationale for retrofitting the building needs to be re-examined."  The confusion over the students is interesting. It seems there were two students, one talked to LeMessurier and one was in touch with a then-junior member at the firm. It's possible that these two people have been confused with each other over the years, possibly by LeMessurier himself, especially since the one that talked directly to LeMessurier wasn't identified until 2011. The student he spoke to personally has written that he was not at all concerned about quartering winds. He was only writing a paper on the building because he was impressed with it. He did mention to LeMessurier that his professor thought it was an irresponsible design because of the placement of the columns. The other student who was in contact with the junior staff member seems to have indicated that she had no qualms with the explanations and assurances from the junior staffer. Her professor seemed to be concerned about the placement of the columns, as other student's professor was, and possibly about the lack of quartering wind calculations given to his student. That raises a lot of questions about that student's quartering wind calculations. The claim is there was concern that the quartering winds produce stresses significantly greater than winds on the faces. But LeMessurier apparently needed to go off to Maine and perform precise calculations to "confirm" this. If it's such a simple calculation that an undergrad can do it in a thesis about the "scientific, social, and symbolic implications" of the building (it's notable that the idea has been raised as to whether these calculations had simply never been done in the course of the project, implying that it was an oversight of something straightforward), then why is the NIST still not sure that the conclusion is accurate and why did LeMessurier need to work so hard to perform them? Something doesn't add up. I mean, the NIST doesn't need to reanalyze it if the student's calculations have much engineering relevancy at all, it would be just "look at what these calculations demonstrate".  Apparently the original wind tunnel information is confidential, per the NIST guy. I wonder, then, if the retests in the wind tunnel (which were performed by the same guy as the initial tests) and the recalculations that led to the repairs are also confidential. I have to wonder if the reason the firm doesn't like to talk about the incident is because they either know or are concerned of the possibility that the repairs were unnecessary. As noted in this video, the story as is hasn't seemed to have been a negative for the firm. But costly, unnecessary emergency repairs would certainly be a detriment to the reputation of the firm as well as tarnishing the story and its hero, which both seem to have taken on a positive mythos in the field of engineering ethics.

When I was a student at Berkley in the early 80's, four of us did a study of the Oakland Colosseum Arena.  The original design had just vertical columns below the "X" bracing. It looked to us, as baby architecture students early in our structural studies, like a "soft story" (lower floor that is less stiff than the structure above it, which is an earthquake hazard).  We called the architect at Skidmore Owings & Merrill.  He said it wasn't a soft story.  In our presentation to the class we said it looked to us like a soft story but the architect said it wasn't.  In the '90's they did a rehab of the building and added big shear walls in the not soft story.  Apparently it was a soft story after all!

Credit to LeMessurier for addressing the flaw.  I take issue with him claiming fixing the mistake was the main ethical issue here.    First he participated in a firm where he knew it was possible the implementation could be different from his specification, ie welds vs bolts. That can‚Äôt be knowingly  allowed to happen.  Second, when a design is radically different from the norm, ie columns not on building corners, then all existing design and building experience is out the window and the new design has to be proven correct under all conditions, and a traditional analysis won‚Äôt do. There can‚Äôt be any, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt do quartering wind analysis‚Äù, or ‚Äúdynamics not necessary‚Äùresponses.  That kind of bottom up design and 100% modeling is expensive, as it should be, and it‚Äôs the reason radical new  building designs are slow to appear.  An engineer in love with his shiny new elegant never seen before design is a dangerous thing.  Giving LeMessurier‚Äôs reputation a pass will allow these design failures to continue to slip into the modern world in an unseen way.

His original design has redundancy for a reason. Every engineering efforts has usually some redundancy just to avoid catastrophe because of unknown factors, yet there are people who want to save money thinking such redundancy is unnecessary just to find out that it was a big mistake in later stages of the projects. 24:37 Dont get me wrong, I totally commend LeMessieur for owning up to it, but I feel like a crucial part of this story is overshadowed by his "heroism" in this situation.   In this clip, I think he overestimates the morality of the "white lies" which will prevent people from a mass panic. We have to remember, this mass panic is totally contingent on them having to be in the building, i.e. not being able to miss work. The real panic is from the companies who will suffer great loss if this ever comes out, or if their employees god forbid prioritize their safety from a potential major disaster. But in reality, it's the people who panics because the companies have the power to  incentivize people not to miss work. They wouldn't be panicking at all if companies were willing to prioritize people over profit. Call it the "harsh reality" that we should just accept but to distort the narrative to this story of one man's difficult choice and duty is simply misleading and reeks of ideology. Again, this is not to chastise LeMessieur, but to point out how he himself was led to believe that a contingent choice was his necessary, moral duty.

Wow that was a cool one. Great story.
This reminds me of the admittedly smaller engineering issue at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in 1981.  Interior sky walks were supported by round stock steel rods for 3 levels. By design the rods were continuous from floor to the ceiling 4 stories up.  But how do you assemble this?  So the builders cut the rods at each sky walk level and bolted them to the walk, slightly offsetting the next rod bolted through the walk on up to the top. During a Tea Dance the skywalks were filled with people and the 2 of the levels sheared off at the rod attachments then sliding down crushing the people between the concrete walks down to ground level. Over 100 died and several hundred more severely injured. Being a designer myself, though of much smaller devices, I will never forget how I felt for the people who made those design changes, and I never made a single change to anything ever again without fully investigating the possible performance results of such a change. Kudos for how this Citicorp group handled this, and even Mother Nature gave them a chance to fix it by making a rather unusual change in her storms flight path. One never really knows about such things.

Grok:  In 1978, an architecture student, later identified as Diane Hartley from Princeton, contacted the chief engineer, William LeMessurier, about a potential flaw. The issue was the building‚Äôs vulnerability to quartering winds (winds hitting the corners), which were not accounted for in the original design, unlike perpendicular winds. Repairs and Impact The discovery prompted secret emergency repairs, including reinforcing joints with steel plates and installing emergency generators for a tuned mass damper. The building was strengthened to withstand a 700-year storm by September 13, 1978, and the story remained confidential until 1995.

Even ignoring the technical details, I'm surprised that nobody thought "what would happen to this building that doesn't have supports on its corners if the wind hits it at a diagonal"   Falling over diagonally is an obvious weakness in this building just by looking at it.
It is almost never mentioned but the architect designer was mainly Peter Woytuk, who died prematurely in the year 1974, years before the building was finished. As the architect Charles Nelson indicates: "One other fact you won‚Äôt find anywhere is that the original design to support the building was not LeMessurier‚Äôs idea, but Stubbins‚Äô architect on the project, Peter Woytuk. Peter was a Director of Hugh Stubbins & Associates, and Vice President of Design. Woytuk sketched out the design on the back of a postcard on the flight back to Boston from his meeting with Citicorp. LeMessurier made that design happen." He continues indicating that he died of a rare blood disease which was not the case. Anyway, in the original design we can see the diagonal beam braces without any bolts, also included and altered in this video. The structural calculation error belongs to LeMessurier as the engineer. The switch to bolts and who approved it remains unclear, but Peter Woytuk was not involved as he died in 1974 just as construction began.

I'm a structural engineer with almost 50 years experience.  I first heard about this story many years ago and I've met Bill LeMessurier.  Quartering winds are important but usually they don't add up to increase forces in braces, the individual engineer has to determine where they are important.  Also the building code doesn't fully credit wind loads depending on the building shape.  The video discusses adding the orthogonal components of wind and this is what would normally be done in practice but in reality the wind load acting on the corner of a square would be reduced by aerodynamic principles, i.e. the building is somewhat streamlined in that direction.  There is a small discount in the building code for shape of some types of structures but it wouldn't apply to an entire building such as this.  In all of the articles and videos I've seen this point was never addressed.  Doing a wind tunnel analysis would of course automatically consider this but hand calculations might not.  The wind tunnel analysis is the ultimate authority because it will consider shielding by surrounding buildings which is important in an area such as NYC.

Over the decades when I was engineering parts for cars, I encountered plenty of "dubious" safety situations. None has this level of responsibility, of course. At worst some driver might be inconvenienced by a breakdown, but risk of injury or death rarely came into it. What shocked me totally, was the universal attitude of "can we get away with it?" No-one cared about responsibility. All that mattered was how much it would cost to fix a flaw, versus getting the end user to pay for the repairs. Reputation? Irrelevant. Ethics? Nope. Last week I saw a video on "10 most lethal cars" and some manufacturers even produced reports on the cost of "death rate versus fixing". Cheaper to leave it lethal and pay the lawsuits... Oh, dear.

AI Summary  *Abstract:*  This video recounts the engineering crisis of the Citicorp Center in the late 1970s. Designed with a unique structure featuring columns at the center of each face to accommodate an existing church, chief engineer Bill LeMessurier employed innovative chevron bracing and a tuned mass damper. However, a design change substituting welded joints for bolts on the braces, combined with an oversight in calculating strength under "quartering winds" (hitting the building diagonally), left the skyscraper vulnerable to collapse in a severe storm. LeMessurier's discovery of this potentially fatal flaw led to a critical ethical dilemma. Choosing public safety over professional reputation, he initiated a secret repair operation (Project Serene) to weld reinforcement plates onto the vulnerable joints, working against the clock during hurricane season. The building narrowly avoided disaster during Hurricane Ella. The story highlights LeMessurier's integrity and has become a celebrated case study in engineering ethics, leading to changes in building codes regarding wind load calculations.  *The Citicorp Center Crisis: A Near Disaster and an Ethical Triumph*  *   *0:00* The Citicorp Center, opened in 1977, was an engineering marvel with a hidden fatal flaw discovered in the summer of 1978 by engineer Bill LeMessurier. *   *1:05* The building's unique design was necessitated by an agreement with Saint Peter's Church (0:01:16), requiring the tower's base to be open, leading to the placement of supporting columns at the center of each side rather than the corners. *   *3:19* LeMessurier designed a chevron bracing system to transfer gravity loads to the central columns and withstand wind loads, a unique solution for a skyscraper. *   *7:50* To mitigate swaying due to the relatively light structure, a novel tuned mass damper (TMD) was installed on the top floor (0:09:49), weighing 400 tons. *   *11:18* The critical flaw was discovered after LeMessurier learned that welded connections on the chevron braces had been substituted with bolts (0:11:45) to save costs. *   *13:59* While rechecking calculations, LeMessurier realized that the bolt connections had only been analyzed for straight-on winds, not "quartering winds" hitting the building diagonally (0:14:06). *   *14:17* Calculations showed that quartering winds could increase forces on some braces by 40%, and dynamic analysis (considering building movement) revealed even higher stresses (0:18:09), potentially exceeding the strength of the bolted joints. *   *17:22* Compounding the issue, the firm had used an incorrect factor of safety and underestimated gravity loads when calculating the required number of bolts, resulting in far fewer bolts (four) than needed (up to ten or more) at critical joints (0:17:00). *   *18:39* LeMessurier calculated that a storm occurring every 67 years could cause collapse, or every 16 years if the TMD lost power (0:19:06). He believed it could fall in his lifetime. *   *19:51* Facing potential professional ruin, bankruptcy, or even considering suicide, LeMessurier chose to inform Citicorp executives (0:20:34) about the risk to public safety (0:20:25). *   *20:41* Citicorp's chairman, Walter Wriston, immediately approved emergency measures, including generators for the TMD (0:20:42) and a secret repair plan called Project Serene (0:20:55). *   *21:10* Project Serene involved welding large steel plates onto over 200 vulnerable joints, working overnight to minimize disruption (0:21:15). *   *21:41* An evacuation plan for a 10-block radius was developed with the Red Cross, though kept secret from the public to avoid panic (0:22:25). Strain gauges and dedicated phone lines were installed for monitoring (0:22:31). *   *25:02* A remarkable coincidence occurred when LeMessurier tried to call The New York Times, only to find the newspaper staff were on strike (0:25:06), resulting in a press blackout that aided the secrecy of the repairs. *   *25:42* The project faced a major threat when Hurricane Ella, a strong storm, headed towards New York in September 1978 (0:25:42). The city prepared for evacuation (0:26:20), but the hurricane turned out to sea at the last minute (0:26:37), narrowly avoiding disaster. *   *26:59* Repairs were completed in October 1978 at a cost of $4-5 million. The building is now considered safe enough to withstand a "one in 1000" storm (0:27:04). *   *27:24* The crisis remained largely secret for almost two decades until a 1995 "New Yorker" article (0:27:29). LeMessurier was widely praised for his ethical conduct (0:27:35). *   *27:42* New York City updated its building code to include requirements for quartering wind calculations (0:27:42). *   *28:08* Tuned mass dampers, pioneered in this skyscraper, are now common in tall buildings worldwide (0:28:08). *   *28:37* The legacy includes controversy over the identity of the student who first raised concerns about the quartering winds (0:28:39), often attributed to Diane Hartley (0:28:51) or Lee DeCarolis (0:31:00), though the exact interaction with LeMessurier remains debated. *   *32:20* The Citicorp Center crisis is widely taught as a prime example of engineering ethics and the professional responsibility engineers have for public safety (0:32:23). Diane Hartley's thesis, titled "Implications of a Major Urban Office Complex: The Scientific, Social and Symbolic Meanings of Citicorp Center, New York City," is indeed subject to specific access restrictions at Princeton University's Seeley G. Mudd Manuscript Library. The strict limitations imposed on the distribution of this thesis are very surprising given its historical importance. As a result, no complete copy is available online. Here are the details: This undergraduate senior thesis, completed in 1978 as part of Hartley's Bachelor of Science in Engineering in Civil Engineering and Operations Research, is archived in the university's DataSpace repository. However, it is designated as "Walk-in Access," meaning it can only be viewed on-site at the Mudd Manuscript Library using designated computer terminals. There is no option for online access or downloading, and reproduction is prohibited without explicit permission. While a request form is available for those seeking copies, approval is not guaranteed and is subject to the library's discretion. Despite the thesis's recognized significance in the history of civil engineering, particularly regarding the Citicorp Center's structural analysis, Princeton University has not provided an official explanation for these access limitations.

Has anyone done a fatigue analysis?  The Citicorp building design is not dissimilar to the design of ships.   When the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System loaded its first tanker in 1977.  Depending on specific designs, fatigue cracks started to appear within a few years.  Over time, more cracks appeared, some in critical areas.  In 1991, the USCG issued a requirement that tankers involved in the TAPS trade develop a critical areas inspection plan.  The plan required identification of critical areas, usually done using finite element analysis, annual inspections of the critical areas, development of approved repairs, and record keeping of cracks and repairs made.  Rules for the design and construction of tankers evolved from the cracks found in tankers in the TAPS trade.  As a side note, the TAPS trade is unique in that it is primarily from Valdez to the US West Coast (Long Beach, San Francisco Bay, and Puget Sound), large number of annual trips, and significant weather.  Steel subjected to cyclical loading, from say varying winds, can result in fatigue cracking.   High stress areas should be visually inspected.  If necessary, non-destructive testing should be included.

03:00 the chair analogy is possibly one of the worst to use here. We have stools. Stools don't tend to have the legs at the corners. But, I get that he was saying still, all force from one side of the building, is now leaning on one leg instead of two. (not how a stool works, its primary concern is downward force) There's then the added problem of the height of the building, when you make something taller and put tension on the top of it, that force goes up exponentially. The single easiest way to demonstrate this, is to grab the remote for your TV mid way, then push from the top. Now try when grabbing it from the bottom. You will feel a difference on the hand holding it steady. Now imagine the remote is the size of the skyscraper. Edit: Also to touch base on the bolts. Think of how easily a nail can be bent with a hammer. Now, realise that this is actually a good thing as the nail doesn't snap. It's a similar enough concept to the bolts. They don't have good shear strength, but they are solid. So the moment they start to bend... Well, very bad things happen. Again, remember that this is many times taller than anything you'd tend to be building, so the forces at play scale astronomically. So no... A screw definitely won't do the same job.

I first heard about the implementation of Tuned Mass Dampers, to reduce the degree to which a tall building would "sway", when I happened to read a Differential Equations textbook that devoted an entire chapter to the troubles of The John Hancock Tower in Boston MA. William LeMessurier, it turns out, got involved with the troubles that the JHT was experiencing, long before the construction phase was even finished, so as to be responsible for the installation of a Tuned Mass Damper, on the tower. The Differential Equations textbook, that I happened to read, concerned itself with the precise calculation of the rate at which the Tuned Mass Damper would "rob" energy from the unwanted "sway" of the tower.

This video raises several questions: 1. Why was the transportation of long diagonal beams across NYC deemed logistically impossibile? This sort of task was apparently achieved eight years earlier when the John Hancock Center was constructed in 1969; the diagonal beams were transported to the Chicago construction site using a combination of methods. Initially, crawler cranes were used to erect the steel from the foundation level up to the second floor. Then, to elevate the steel further, four "S2" towers with stiff-leg derricks were employed, supporting the erection from the second floor to the roof. These derricks had a capacity of 50 tons at a 30-foot radius and a maximum radius of 120 feet. The hoist engines for these derricks were located within the towers, which were "jumped" every four floors, allowing for the construction to proceed efficiently. 2.  Why should a tuned structural damper be at the mercy of a power outage? Surely a battery backup system could be installed to tide them over? Besides, according to my source, the Citigroup Center in NYC does NOT have a tuned mass damper, instead it has a tuned system that uses a fluid to dampen vibrations and reduce sway - this requires a very modest amount of electrical power. 3.  Does the wind loading hazard increase or diminish with time? On the one hand predicted climate change will increase the severity of hurricanes in the years to come. On the other hand, as more and more extreemely tall buidlings are erected each decade, shouldn't these act as wind breaks that reduce the wind load on earlier structures?

I've been somewhere similar for this.  I was working as shop electric/warehouse for a company that rented lighting equipment to film studios when l decided to autopsy a few of our tube lights that had to be replaced at a shoot, just to see why they quit working. I found that the live wires feeding the light had been pinched to the metal housing during assembly in every failed tube, and they had shorted out through the chassis to an outside ground. I then decided to open up a dozen or so good lights from our stock to see if any others had this problem, and was shocked to find that about 2 in ten had that flaw, and the only thing stopping people from getting electrocuted by them was the paint on the outside and luck. I immediately brought this up to the manager and the experienced electrician, but was sorta handwaved off that it wasn't a big deal.  I didn't know what to think. The last few years had been rough on me, life was only starting to get back on track, l didn't want to lose my job and start all over. There was no certainty that this was as big of a problem as l was worried it could be, l could easily have been mistaken since l was new to the industry, and motivated reasoning made this a very attractive thought, but l resolved to bring it up again the next day and prepared to start contacting authorities on my own if l was ignored. Fortunately, the previous day had mostly been a miscommunication when they thought l was only referring to some bent ground tabs inside the lights. The manager immediately froze all of their use once l showed him one light running only through alligator leads from the frames of two other units that were separately shorting to hot and neutral, and there was a conference call within the hour with the engineer who produced them. I spent much of the next few months inspecting and clearing the good units, culling the dangerous ones, and working on a fix for all the ones getting produced in the future.   The part that struck me the most wasn't risking my own well being, that would have been an easy call if l knew others would be in serious danger otherwise. It was the uncertainty, the very real chance of throwing everything away over nothing, that there was no actual danger and l was just mistaken.
