It‚Äôs crazy that the architects and engineers already reduced the budget through smart design and thoughtful planning. Then some other people in the firm got cheap and chose to cut more by using bolts instead of welds.
The first person to discover the fatal flaw in the design of the Citicorp Center (now known as Citigroup Center) in New York was a civil engineering student named Diane Hartley in 1978.  At the time, Diane was writing her thesis on the building and realized there was a serious potential problem with the structure regarding quartering winds ‚Äî wind coming from diagonal directions ‚Äî something that hadn‚Äôt been fully accounted for in the original design.  Her findings led William LeMessurier, the building‚Äôs chief structural engineer, to investigate further. After digging into it, LeMessurier himself confirmed there was a critical weakness in the bolted joints of the building‚Äôs frame, which could cause the tower to collapse under strong diagonal winds.

0:40 These are the situations that separate scientist from frauds.  It is like when you are about to publish a manuscript in which you have worked the whole year, and doing the tenth routine revision of all your results you notice this time that there is a minus sign missing in one of your scripts to plot the data, and when corrected, your manuscript falls apart.  I have been in that situation last year and I can tell you that I stayed immobile for 5 minutes, not even thinking, just feeling my heart pound as if it was trying to break my rib cage. I needed that manuscript to apply for the position I wanted, and with this revelation, basically my life plans had been destroyed. But after 5 minutes I did what I had to do. I called my supervisor, I told him about the situation and that I would inform him by the end of the day hopefully of the full extend of the damage. Once evaluated, I would email the very prestigious journal in my field which had already accepted the paper for publication, and retract it. For two hours I was just a destroyed man, but I knew that I was doing what was right. Not just because I knew that it was right, but because scientific integrity is one of those things that you only get once, and if you destroy, you will never fully recover it, if you recover any of it at all. Just like someone's trust. From an honorable perspective, which is the one I hope I was taking, I was doing it because I am ultimately doing science for the good of Humanity and publishing wrong results is antithesis to my goal. But even from a selfish perspective, it is better to endure the momentary soul-crushing experience, than to be caught and relegated to a life of ostracism.  We scientist sometimes joke that just before publishing something, we do not want to look to much more into our results so as to not find something wrong. Because if you publish something wrong unknowingly, you just need to own it publicly and retract those results. But once you know, there is no going back to be "unaware".  The conclusion of the story is actually of elation. Myself from the past knew that I would do this and that, so I already took that minis sign into account (not literally a minus sign, but it can happen sometimes), so once you go through the whole process you get not only the correct result, but a better result that you would get by keeping the "minus sign" in its original place, instead of taking it into account later. I was almost crying when I called my supervisor to tell him that everything was right, that I found why there was no "minus sign" there.  The first lesson to learn: It is always better both for your honor and your career to endure the momentary sorrow and soul-crushing experience, than to live a life of shame and shunning from your community. The second lesson to learn: Never read in diagonal for a final cross-check. Yourself from the past probably did something clever that yourself from today is not going to catch it at first and you are going to have a heart attack. If you are doing a final cross-check, do it careful and step by step. Your heart can only take a few of these before needing an ambulance.

Nice video, I went through civil engineering (structural sub-specialty)  in the mid 1970's at a Canadian university prior to the events in this episode. After graduation I went into a different branch of engineering. The architecture/structural complexity wave was really just beginning back then. We had a guest lecturer describe the design and construction of the CN Tower in Toronto. The topic of engineering lifespan of structures came up. My question of how you bring down a structure at the end of its service life was met with a blank stare. The problem I see with modern structures is the old form versus function debate. To become a successful architect you need to innovate and create complexity. I pity future generations who will have to deal with decommissioning these structures. I often wonder if this issue is addressed within modern practice and building codes. Maybe it is as simple as reversing the order of everything you did to build in the first place. We studied this as part of an Ethics in Engineering course. An interesting example of accountability and communication.  We spent a great deal of time discussing the decision to conduct the work at night, without informing the public. Was it the right decision?  I generally think so as it could have created more panic and delayed the changes.  However, others in my class (and I see their point) just saw it as a way to avoid getting sued.  At its core, it highlights the difficulty in communicating technical problems to the general population. It creates what I see as a modern issue in science: "trust the science" vs anti-establishment sentiments.  For example, the COVID mitigation measures and vaccine; where scientists scrambled to meet a pandemic. I am sure students will sit in ethics courses studying these efforts, now with the benefit of hindsight.

I'm sorry, but it was intuitively obvious to me the instant I saw the building that diagonal wind loads were going to be the problem. In a normal building, supported at the corners, the face-on wind loads are the biggest problem, because that's the narrowest part of the supporting polygon, and as we all know, the stiffness of anything depends heavily on its thickness. With supports at the midpoint of the sides like this, the supporting polygon is actually only the diamond between them, so the scariest wind load is the one face-on to THAT polygon, not to the actual building.

If it can withstand a 1-in-1000 years storm now, that's equivalent to saying it'll be blown over in a storm that occurs about once per 1,000 years statistically. That means that there's a ~10% chance (to be exact 1-1/exp(100/1000)=9.52%) that it'll be blown over in the next 100 years. So a 9.5% chance for a 9/11-like super disaster in the next 100 years that would be completely foreseeable and preventable. That doesn't sound very acceptable does it?

A revolutionary new building that relies on brand new stabilizing methods, topples over and takes a bunch of other buildings and countless lives with it. that would be one of the biggest disasters in the city's history. Our country went to war with multiple countries over 9/11, I think they could probably set up a pretty intense manhunt of this guy if he tried to flee or cover it up. I also think the cover-up was wildly irresponsible of him. Personally, I don't buy the excuse of "not wanting to cause a mass panic." Thousands of people were in critical danger that this man knew about and could tell them about, but he didn't. Instead, he conspired with the city and the bank's CEO to make the repairs in secret. This literally delayed the fix; construction could only happen at night, so as not to raise suspicion. I imagine if he did fess up to the public, there would have been panic; rightfully so, tbh. But what there also would have been is an official emergency response to the situation to make sure it is resolved as quickly and soundly as possible. Maybe I am cynical, but I think fear of legal issues and career destruction were the predominant motives behind LeMessurier's actions here. For those of you who know about the student who asked the question about quartering winds, she IS mentioned late in the video.  The problem was discovered a year after completion, in 1978. An undergraduate student named Diane Hartley at Princeton was doing her undergraduate thesis under David bellington.  Hartley's concerns and the reactions she received are documented in her thesis. She raised questions about the stability in the face of winds blowing at the edges, a factor not considered in the standards of that time.

I get the impression in how this story is told that there were questions being raised by multiple sources and LeMessurier and his team decided to recheck things. Seems to me that Lee DeCarolis made the phone call that LeMessurier took and that got him thinking. It also seems to me that the Diane Hartley's thesis paper was photocopied and sent to the engineering firm. This sets LeMessurier doing the step-by-step process of understanding 1) was his office's design sufficient, 2) was the contractor's construction documents at variance from the design, 3) was the variance sufficient to meet design requirements, 4) was the actual installation in agreement with the construction documents. That's how the bolts problem shows up. At some point before or during this process Hartley's thesis finds the desk of someone involved in the checking steps described above. He goes to Maine to work in solitude to confirm that it's a genuine issue as described in Veritasium's video. He powers through the self-doubt, self-destructive thoughts, etc. and realizes he must get the thing fixed. Thank goodness the head of CitiCorp agreed that it simply must be done immediately and the ball was rolling. Lives have been saved. Several hurricanes have come through New York since. Any one of them could have brought that building down killing many thousands. There should be some kind of award named after him. It was brave, selfless, grand, and well-executed.

I love me some Veritasium content but this particular video is an example of a growing problem with social media and viral content.  This story about the Citicorp building's original design and perceived fatal flaw is by no means new or unexamined.  It's been addressed in DOZENS of YouTube videos alone.  The redundancy of the topic might be forgivable but few of these videos reflect more recent analysis that has concluded via computer modeling that in fact the building was NOT in danger of being toppled by high winds.    The players didn't know it at the time given the tools available to them but continuing to sell this story as one of a building facing imminent collapse is a bit click-baity.  Also, it's not a terribly good story of public ethics either, given the original story of the original understanding was kept under wraps for 17 years from 1978 to 1995 when it came to light via a New Yorker story.

First, really enjoy your channel.  This episode is a poster-boy in 'why engineers use computers' now.  As a retired engineer with a background in FEA analysis (I actually wrote FEA code for several commercial products), a relatively inexpensive finite element model of the building subjected to a suite of static and dynamic loads would have caught ALL of these problems.  Who the heck is/was doing hand calculations of complex structures (like this building) even in 1978? Trust me, finite elements were being used in the analysis of complex structures long before 1978.  The accuracy of the results and the number of use cases handled far exceed what could be done with hand calcs.  Just silly.
